reviewText:
Crusaders of the Lost Idols is one that I'd recommend for casual gamers. This is definitely a click-fest, so get your trigger finger ready and dust off the mouse pad.

The graphics are clear and vivid, and some of the characters are truly expressive and unique. Levels are pretty much endless, as monsters will continue to generate.

There is also a strategy to this game, as character upgrades and character formation can increase your loot and reduce the amoutn of clicking that's required.

You'll also find a social aspect with in-game chat, daily activities, and a very good soundtrack. I decided to check out this game during a promotion, and it was definitely entertaining.

It does contain some steam achievements, but the in-game achievements are much more attainable. For those who specifically look for games with the intention of maxing out achievements, keep in mind that you're in it for the long haul.

If, however, you're looking for a casual game that you can play at your desk over a lunch break without becoming too involved in a campaign, or a game that you can build up to the point where it pretty much functions on its own, then this is a game you might enjoy.

reviewText:
Crusaders of the Lost Idols is a clicker game, well, unless you're recruiting characters that will deal damage for you. Set in a fantasy world, your goal is to pass through levels, with your party which is moving by itself and with enemies coming to you. Complete the quest of the level to access the next one. Every five levels, you get a boss to kill, which gives a chest. The latter hides cards with permanent bonus, new gears, new clothes or buffs to use during a quest.

The money you're collecting will serve to upgrade your characters, to recruit new ones or to unlock new abilities. Some of them are specific to your character, others will affect those next or in front of you while special ones will be used during the levels. In other words, each character can be useful.... if only you weren't stuck to 10 characters maximum.

That's the core of this free-to-play. Only chests are for now a paying item if you want to advance faster.

The graphics are quite cheerful and colorful, the soundtrack is nice. I must say that you don't need an account somewhere to play it. However, you can play it elsewhere and link both accounts.

I'm just disappointed that in-game achievements aren't counted here. Apparently, you need to reset the world (where you don't loose your acquired trinkets for example) so that Steam is considering that achievements can be unlocked. I don't know as I need to reach the requirements for it.

Anyway, the game is surprisingly addictive and simple to handle. Cards are just bonus, you don't have to build a deck, which is a relief for me. Given the fact that it's free, without account to make, give it a shot. Be warned though, you may find it slow without chests. I could enjoy the potential of this game thanks to orly and its key giveaway.

reviewText:
Crusaders of the Lost Idols is currently the best ‘clicker’ game out there. It offers significantly better illusion of control than pretty much any other idle game I’m aware of without ever making you feel stressed, straining the brain cells too much, or introducing any kind of competitive element (there is no leaderboard, no clans and no pvp).

Of course, it is an idle game and your results will therefore vary depending on your tolerance for such things – Call of Duty or Civilization this is not. You’ll either like this style of relaxed micro-progression or you won’t and if you don’t Crusaders isn’t going to change your mind.

Like most other idle games, play consists of completing a run, resetting for boosts (idols), then running the game again to get a little bit further next time. This is a bit more interesting than many other idle games, however, as there are five different 'maps' to run each with half a dozen objectives of varying difficulty to complete (as well as short-term event-only maps at least monthly).

You start with a basic bench of 20 crusaders that you unlock as a run progresses. Depending on the objective between 9 and 13 of these crusaders can be added to your base formation in various ways to increase overall damage (dps), add other buffs (like heal or splash/aoe damage) or to generate more gold. More crusaders can be unlocked during frequent events.

A fair bit of the thought in this game is about tinkering with your formation to squeeze an extra few percent out of things, one way or another. In practice, however, the boosts gained are pretty marginal as your damage is multiplied fourfold every 4-5 zones anyway. It’s an idle game, after all, don’t expect it to burst any brain cells.

One of the particularly nice things about the game is the built in chat server. 99% of the players are really chill and helpful – it’s a lovely community – and that certainly helps to pass the time while watching the ridiculous numbers spiral up into unpronounceable multiples of infinity. (You can, however, turn the chat window off if you find that kind of thing distracting.)

The devs are extremely active, with new events at least every month, new crusaders to mix up your formation, and the occasional addition of new objectives and achievements to aim for. They also pop into chat regularly to discuss the game and are enthusiastic and approachable.

There’s been plenty enough content added already to have maintained my interest for five months straight, with more additions regularly being added – none of these are particularly onerous or complex and all of which are well integrated into the game’s basic systems (unlike, say, the tacked-on additions of some other clicker games, such as Clicker Heroes).

The game’s free to play income model is pretty reasonable. There is the option to buy additional chests for a chance at gear to increase the stats on crusaders (these chests also drop normally during play).

Additionally, every event there is also a ‘free’ ‘golden epic’ awarded for buying two chests ($2.99), and these are typically a little overpowered in one way or another.

Regular players generally see the occasional purchase as a nice way to throw a couple of bucks at the developers, although if you are a collect-the-lot type who is a little cash-strapped you might resent the implied pressure to buy so that you don't 'miss out'. The best any gear can do, however, is help you to get 3-4 zones further before hitting a wall and needing to reset.

It’s not a pay to win model in my view because, well, there’s no actual winning nor is there any direct player vs player interaction. The only ‘win’ to be had here is something to boast about in the in-game chat. But seriously, the developers have to make some cash to fund development and in the scheme of things this is pretty mild.

This game really surprised me.  It's an incredibly simple concept, your crusaders are walking along, enemies show up, and they kill them, gold drops, you level up, ad nausium.  The game designers have managed to turn it into a surprisingly deep bit of strategy with combinations of gear, formations, abilities, missions, etc that all interact so that no experience of the game is the same until much later when you've got most of the gear and the math begins to flatten out.

The time recorded in game is a bit deceptive, as I leave it running in the background.  Actual interaction time is FAR lower, that said it's an epic grind to get all the campaigns completed and will likely take you months or years of on-off play unless you shell out lots of $$$.

It won't win any awards for exciting action, but it's a fun little game to play at work in 1-2 minute spurts

reviewText:
the fact that i've played this for an hour now and loved every glance up at the screen is shocking AF to me.

more shocking? i'm enjoying the upgrade paths, the formation management, all the little details no click-fest requires but that this one has SO MUCH that i'm going to revisit this review with better depth later.

completely unexpected and completely wonderful.

///// A DAY LATER, IN AWE...

OK, the fact that this game is SO much more than a masterclass in happy hypnotism is amazing. there are actual systems at play here.

you will get attached to characters the longer they click for you and keeping some of them in line with the abilities of ones you can pick up later can be a very expensive (but wonderful) habit to keep. (i squealed in glee when my Insane (for real this time) ageing hermit wearing tiny little antlers on his knit cap dealt 103B DPS the first time - worth every one of the hundreds of trillions of gold coins it cost to get him there).

playing with character upgrades and skills with their formation is so smartly set up and left for the player to explore and play with, swapping gals and guys in and out of your lineup to see what changes occur is so deep it's like spinning around a gravity well.

and they don't stop marching onward (in place. ahahaha)

that adorable voodoo doctor owl and THAT GRIFIN - hug them and kiss them and give them anything they want because you will lose count of the times they save those you place ahead of them.

i seriously expected NOTHING from this game. (it's possible i actually started playing it by accident with an errant double click). BUT it's a magical combination of mindless not mindless, non-click clicking, grind that grinds itself while you're away - it has cute quest goals and cute monsters (that kill you) - my little ponies ON FIRE charging through your front lines, casper the VERY unfriendly ghost tearing through your entire party with a goofy smile and googely eyes...

last i checked i have over 9,000 pieces of pumpkin pie and so many other reasons to just play and laugh (the game is brilliant enough that you can also NOT play and still progress - (the non-SRS BSNS version of EVE online's skill queue?).

five words i never thought i'd write: a clickfest grinder of joy.

last words:  i've NEVER liked this sort of game before, let alone loved it.

(i'm 200+ hours into The Wild Hunt since august, Nobunaga's Ambition 14, am loving keeping my own notes while getting lost in Serpent In The Staglands, etc)

give it a shot.

you can always make more dopamine later.

reviewText:
3rd generation Clicker/Idle game, with some very novel new ideas bringing the whole genre forward, 9/10!

Time Clickers (2nd gen) brought the aiming part to the genre, and this game brings formations and that you can actually die/wipe with your team to the genre!
There are different campaigns, each tells a simple story with x numbers of stages, and the # heroes, all with unique skills, you can take with you varies between the missions. What is even more important, they have special goals (e.g. only 1 hero, or double speed of monsters, or double monsters, or less gold earned, or random slots blocked...) which makes each mission quite unique. And that is because of the formtions... as DPS and other skills depend, who is next to whom, and who is in front... and even after 100h, you are forced to try new combos and discover new optimal order how to place them to get max Dps or max Gold... New chars can be played for in special, timed missions... which adds even more variety.
A small warning to the devs/new players... these new char events are almost getting too many/frequent, as some of the normal missions take several weeks to complete, and I dont want to cancel them just to be able to play in a timed event (normally 1 week), as its the only way to get the new chars! 2nd warning: After ca. 1500 Idols, a lot of grinding is required, and the remaining missions take forever to complete (prediction you need min. 15000! but each playthrough gives you ca. 50-70)... this will soon make me stop the game... but I have more than 200h+ in it with a lot of fun, likely currently the best and most complex idle/Clicker game out there... so get it if you like this kind of games!

reviewText:
Wow, where do I begin? This game is an excellent next step in the idle game genre, but I really don't think you need to be a fan of idle games to enjoy it. Unlike most idle games I've tried, it really is a fun game first: the fact that you progress even while the game is closed just feels like a bonus feature.

The biggest differentiator from most idle games is the formation system, where in addition to pouring upgrades into heroes you also have to place them on the battlefield. Crusaders have skills that affect the heroes around them, making it a really fun puzzle game to try and maximize your damage in different ways. Unlocking new Crusaders, formations, and equipment open up a lot of really cool options for formations that keep the game fresh and interesting even after you've played it for a long time ( I'm glad Kongregate doesn't track time, and I'm a little worried now that the game is on Steam!).

Another crucial thing is the reset system in this game: in most idle games you can reset your progress for some bonuses, but then it just feels like you're playing the game over again but faster. In Crusaders when you reset you get bonuses as well, but you also have the option of taking on really crazy challenges for a run instead of just playing the normal game. Challenges that change the formation really bring out that puzzle game feeling, and you learn techniques and tricks from them that you can use in your normal games when you try to go for deep dives ( going as far as possible before resetting ).

I know this review is pretty glowing, but every problem I've had with the game over the months I've been playing has been addressed by the devs, and there's no sign that the updates are slowing down. I've been really impressed with their open communication with the players, it's not something you get from every developer these days.

reviewText:
Raising the bar for clickers.  Because you know, that bar was so high.
TL;DR - If clicker games are your thing, you'll enjoy this one.  It has most of what made Clicker Heroes so great, with a little more strategy.

This game has everything that has made similar games of the genre so successful: heroes, skills, levels, addictiveness, and the never-ending loop of getting stronger, beating quests, and trying to overcome that next boss.  But it takes it a step further with main quests.  Before you begin the game, and each subsequent time you perform a world reset, you will have to choose a main quest before you start.  A main quest is an overall goal set for you for that particular run, and it comes with a nice reward of the in-game currency that can also be bought with cash.  There are also a few worlds these quests take place in, so you won't always be seeing the same backgrounds and monsters as you progress, which helps freshen up the environments you will be seeing over and over.

This game is also more strategical in how it's played versus other clicker games.  In most clicker games, you can buy every hero and they all add DPS to your total.  In Crusaders, each world that you visit requires a unique formation that varies in shape and quantity/size.  For example, the initial formation you will use allows for 10 heroes.  From there, you will unlock other worlds, that require different formations.  This is where the strategy comes into play.  Sometimes you will have to swap out multiple characters to see what gives you the best DPS.  There are also quite a few heroes that offer nice DPS bonuses to heroes in the same row, in front of them, behind them, or all heroes.  You'll also get a few heroes that give you insane gold bonuses, but at the cost of low DPS.  You will soon be testing what works best between heavy hitters, and weaker units to bolster those powerhouses.

There is a Halloween event up as of me writing this, which has a formation allowing for 12 in a unique Halloween world. It's a limited time event so I've recently reset and chosen that world.  What the game failed to tell me was that in 1 of the slots, I have a Witch that screams, giving all adjacent heroes -2% or -4% DPS for each monster on the screen.  The reason I mention this is because this Witch is in the middle of my formation, causing me to be a bit more selective with who I put around her.

There aren't many negatives to the game.  The sound is nothing memorable, but not awful.  I was going to say the graphics are mediocre, but compared to games like Adventure Capitalist, whose only animation is bars, or even Clicker Heroes, whose only animation is the monsters when clicked, this game actually has animation.  So that's a plus.  All in all, it's a pretty good clicker with more depth than most.  My strategy, a.k.a. possible spoiler but something you will inevitably figure out as you play so not really a spoiler:

In the end, Nate Dragon will end up doing 99% of your DPS, so the best strategy is to keep people around him that give him % DPS bonuses.  Basically have everyone give Nate DPS buffs or give your party gold buffs.  Always use the sleuth at end-game and put him in the biggest column, and use the gold bear/lion, and ALWAYS use Natalie Dragon because of the buff she gives Nate.  Profit.

Speaking of profit, if you've come this far, enjoy a free legendary item that gives Nate Dragon a 200% base DPS increase:  NATE-932D-42BB-BOOM  (the code input screen is on the same screen you buy/open chests)

reviewText:
I have just unistalled the game now after playing (although it was mostly idlying with my computer open) for over 150 hours over the course of a few months and several events. Do I recommend this game? The answer is no.
And here is why:
First of all, what is important for me in games is how they are able to bring me happiness and more importantly long term happiness because I remember the wonderful experiences I had with that game. This game however has none of that, now that I uninstalled it I feel relieved because i am free from it's pressure, it's urges that it created through this kind of gaming to just play forward for the short term, one small little feeling of 'progressing' a little bit more although there is no real progress here, no story, no real achievement. The only 'achievements' in this game are robotic tasks such as achivements for clicking a certain number of times or gathering x gold and so on and so forth there are dozenz of them and at the end there is nothing really from this. All the campaigns in the game including the event campaigns (although the developer does give plenty of those in the course of a few months) are rather small, especially after spending a bit of time with the game and they only offer about 100 mini-level maps with lazy objectives with no real challenge in terms of having players play the game. They are all just about boosting your Damage per second and letting the crusaders idle.
The areas are all recycled and if you get to area 101 in any campaign it's actually area one again and it goes on like this, you just get bigger numbers for the levels.
Besides this, the game has microtransactions. Not any kind of microtransactions but microtransactions with random results. Every crusader in this game has only 3 items with 4 tiers each. This implies in reality that after you get an item you will mostly be getting lots and lots of duplicates while waiting for a random drop for the epic and paying real money for that random drop. I had my main DPS crusader get 55 duplicates. 55!!!! Imagine that. And I didn't even buy the magic jewelled chests with real money, My frustration with the game would have been even bigger had I spent 40 euros to get useless duplicates of the same thing. I know randomness has an appeal for some but for me it's a frustrating business model. This now links to my main issue with the game.
To get those 55 duplicates it took me a lot. I mean a real lot. More than resetting 60 times, and that's a lot of time actually wasted in real life. Time wasted to just grind through the same recycled levels lots of times. I wonder what that is doing to my brain really...In any case I am done with idle games. But back to the matter at hand. I put a lot of time in the game and although now I can get to a much further area than in the beginning I still don't really feel any satisfaction since it just goes on and on and on, the areas get recycled and new numbers are added. If you want to get far in this game you have to play it a lot, and reset a lot...and it takes a lot to get to the point of resetting. Especially in the beginning. Either that or you need to pay to get gold and damage boosters and items so I couldn't honestly recommend this game as a relaxing pleasant experience for other customers to relax in their daily lives. It's more of a very stressfull experience.
My next qualm is with the events. Although there were events like every month or every 2 or three weeks which each had a few objectives and some new but really not that usefull crusaders unless you decided to put real money on them, these events are really a big source of pressure. I mean, every one of these events sends out a mail to tell you the event has started. You go in but you can't really do much since on every event you need to accumulate a certain currency for that event which means you have to grind when that event is active. I grinded for a month before and didn't like it. Ok...New event is up, I have to grind again to get the currency which is only available that week. And then these events are always limited in time with achivements which are really grindy- one of them is actually to spend, that's right, spend 17.500 or something like that of that event currency. See what I mean, just earn it to spend id, big grind with no real purpose, no satisfaction. The game with its event and pressure I feel only hammers on the urge to get more achievements which in the long term gives no real gaming value.
My last claim with the game is that it automatically puts you in a game chat with other people who play. The game is not competitive so you don't need it, but still you are automatically put there and I was enjoying it for a bit when playing it at the beginning because other players shared their experience... But that went untill I asked something and some idiot decided to randomly insult me because that's the case of things especially when Steam links you into a sepparate account for this game only and you will meet lots of other people who play but don't have any real tools to interact with them and sanction them for this kind of behaviour since it's just pretty much a random chat. So that really made my experience unenjoyable, especially since it's a single player game and you have to ignore that chat. I later found out that you can disable it, but I don't know why it was on there in the first place because when the community is not solid and it's not because of these sepparate umoderated accounts, you get this behavior. That's a another reason why I like steam because I can choose who to interact with completely.
To sum up, if you are a new player who wants to try this game I would advise against it. It takes a very long time to get anywhere, the satisfaction is not really great and you might end up like me regretting the experience. If you put dozens of dollars on it and you only got duplicates and random trinkets to just get you past a few more levels you will definitely regret it. And generally I think the idle genre is just an empty marketing thing, with no real gaming value, so it will probably hook you up for a few months then make you regret you didn't play the Witcher or any other story-rich game during that time which will give you fond memories for decades to come. Speaking of that, I got more time on this than I have on each title of the Witcher...I might solve that :).

It's free, it's your time. But it's not a quick cheevo run as you get 1 cheevo per run. Negative time waster advise.

This game is getting worse with each crusader update. New crusader replacements are getting introduced every 8 weeks now. There's hardly time to finish a single run. Although the idea of formations and using crusaders (heroes) and the interactions between is nice. The use of alternative crusaders is pretty much useless as you will not be able to upgrade them after the initial 10 day period of getting them. Any chests (either bought with rubies or received through boss kills) only drop upgrades for the regular crusaders anyway. So in the end it doesn't make much sense in building a strategy based on alternative crusaders.

Although I initially like this idle/clicker game, I am seriously getting bored because I focussed too much on getting these alternative crusaders, some of them being extremely useless anyway.

reviewText:
Oooh, this game is a lot of fun.

I've been playing Clicker Heroes for hundreds of hours and figured I'd check out a new clicker game.

Great execution of the clicker genre of games. Not only do you unlock new heroes, you place them in formation (10 on screen at a time) and certain ones will interact with others causing bonuses to damage and such.

On top of that, there are the expected items to gain that boost damage and gold gains.

The biggest difference I noticed, between this one and Clicker Heroes, is that this one scrolls from left to right, as if the characters are walking through the forest or environment.

Additionally, if the monsters get to your heroes, they actually damage and can kill them for that round, causing you to need to go back a level and earn more gold.

The interface is great, easy to pickup and understand, and the gameplay is just fun.

There's also XP gain, which means that after 5 hours of having a hero in formation, their DPS will double due to XP gained. It's a small but nice touch.

There's really a lot to like about this game, and it's done something very right with its entering the clicker scene. Not only has it got its own charm and style, it sets itself apart enough from the crowd that it has managed to truly bring something new to the scene.

Certainly worth your download.

Truly, this game is the absolute bottom of the barrel in terms of idle/clicker games.  I will start by saying this, the game mechanic is fun and the game itself is enjoyable.  The team formatting is unique and diverse.

That being said.

This game represents all of the unbridled greed that game developers seem to find themselves filled with these days.  In terms of raw micro-transaction COST, this game is the most expensive game on the market.

In addition, this game has been out for quite some time on Kongregate.com prior to being released on Steam.  As a game developer I find Kongregate to be a great community and I've enjoyed seeing other titles such as AdVenture Capitalist, Time Clickers, and Clicker Heroes make amazing transitions over to the Steam community.

The same can NOT be said for this game.
Why?

All the aforementioned titles all had one thing in common.  If you spent money on in-game micro-transactions on Kongregate ALL of those bonuses carried over to the Steam platform.  Players were given the ability to Export" their save game code and then "Import" it once on Steam.

Even for idle/clicker games that are only on Kongregate this is common practice.  At this point it has become an expected "best practices" within the industry.

Crusaders of the Lost Idols does NOT do this.

Kongregate users have been calling for ages for the ability to import/export save codes.  Even more-so once it was announced that this title would be being released on Steam.  Users repeatedly reached out to the developers attempting to make contact with them.  The devs were silent for over 4 months.

reviewText: I feel like this game kinda misses the point of a clicker game.  When I'm looking for a clicker game, I want a game that will allow me to endlessly (other than at the limit of my patience and diligence) build upon my stats.  There's too much strategy involved in Crusaders of the Lost Idols.  You can only have up to 10 characters in your party at a time which requires you to pick and choose your team based on their abilities and stats and how they interact with each other.  It's too much RPG, not enough clicker genre in my opinion.\n\nIf you like complicated clickers though, I'm sure it's a lot of fun.
